p: Originally, this plant was cultivated for its leaves, whose nutritional potential is exploited to fight against malnutrition (Fuglie, 2002; Ndong, Wade, Dossou, & Guiro, 2007). In addition, leaf extracts show hypocholesterolemic and hypotensive activities (Gilani et al., 1994; Mehta, Balaraman, Amin, Bafna, & Gulati, 2003). The seeds show antimicrobial activity against fungi and bacteria (Donli & Dauda, 2003), and antitumor (Bharali, Tabassum, & Azad, 2003) and anti‐inflammatory activity. Studies on seeds are much accentuated on the purification of water and the oil extraction. The oil has a good stability for cooking and good technological aptitudes for frying (Abdulkarim, Long, Lai, Muhammad, & Ghazali, 2005; Anwar, Bhanger, & Kazi, 2003). However, studies on the nutritional composition and functional properties of defatted M. oleifera flour are scarce and show that they are a good underexploited protein source (Govardhan Singh, Ogunsina, & Radha, 2011).
